title-group.article-title: Zinc oxide/aluminum-based self-powering storage system fabricated using selectively direct-write ultraviolet-curable resin method

abstract.p: This article presents a flexible piezoelectric harvester based on a polyethylene terephthalate cantilever system to scavenge vibration energy. It comprises a low-voltage drop rectifying circuit and an electrolytic capacitor to store the induced voltage. The harvester was made in the form of a composite plate that consists of flexible aluminum/polyethylene terephthalate vibration plate, piezoelectric zinc oxide thin film, and selectively deposited ultraviolet-curable resin lump structures as proof mass, which were directly constructed on the rear side of the polyethylene terephthalate-based composite plate using electrospinning with a stereolithography technique. Aluminum was sputtered on the polyethylene terephthalate substrate as the bottom electrode because of superior adhesion with the polyethylene terephthalate and zinc oxide film, compared with indium tin oxide film. Finite element analysis simulations were used to analyze the operation frequency and output voltage of the piezoelectric composite plate. The experimental results show that the maximal open-circuit voltage was 2.4 V and the close-circuit voltage was 2.18 V, which is 0.56 µW/cm2. After rectification, a direct current voltage of 2 V across the capacitor can be achieved. The self-powered storage system can drive the warning signal of the light-emitting diode module in both resonant and nonresonant conditions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the past few years, various approaches in developing clean and green energy systems have been extensively explored. Especially, vibration-based power harvesters that harvest ambient vibration using microelectromechanical (MEMS) system technology have attracted considerable attention. Recent work in the field of piezoelectric harvesters has shown considerable progress toward small size, lightweight, high power density, and environmentally friendly. In applications, microsystems must be self-powered; therefore, efficient energy scavenging is crucial. The self-powered microsystems were designed to avoid the replacement of energy cells and miniature sensing devices. They must be embedded batteries, which is not convenient in real applications. A possible solution was the design of a micro generator at the same scale as actuators, sensors, and electronics (Wang et al., 2006). Therefore, we present a self-powered storage system of a flexible piezoelectric power harvester that may be an independent power source without a connection to the outside source.

Several studies focused on the electrical–mechanical coupling effects from various ambient energy sources. Roundy et al. (2005) improved the trapezoidal geometry to supply twice the energy of the rectangular geometry. Fang et al. (2006) used a silicon-based piezoelectric cantilever with a metal mass at the free end. At the resonant frequency of 608 Hz, 890 mV alternating current (AC) voltage value was measured. Liu et al. (2008) designed a power generator array based on thick-film piezoelectric cantilevers. Effective electrical power of 3.98 mW and 3.93 direct current (DC) voltage output were achieved to improve the power output. Koyamau and Nakamura (2010) proposed an energy harvesting system using a polyurea piezoelectric thin film, which has a thinner and shorter cantilever configuration to enhance the conversion efficiency. The numerous studies on piezoelectric energy harvesters have mainly focused on (Pb, Zr)TiO3 (PZT) piezoelectric ceramic materials. Xu et al. (2010) developed a piezoelectric device based on a conventional PZT bulk ceramic beam with an extended auxiliary part that formed a right angle relative to the basic part. The right-angle cantilever produced more electrical energy compared to a traditional cantilever. Lee et al. (2009) compared the {3–1} mode with the {3–3} piezoelectric mode to fabricate a PZT thin film. The {3–3} mode can supply twice the output voltage of the {3–1} mode. Several vibration harvesting devices were proposed in Kok et al. (2008), Jeong et al. (2005), and Wang and Ko (2010). However, the use of piezoelectric PZT devices has been restricted because of environment-related issues. This study selected zinc oxide (ZnO) as the main element of piezoelectric thin films because of the following advantages: (1) it has a high piezoelectric coupling coefficient (Lin et al., 2007, 2008), (2) production of ZnO thin films does not cause environmental pollution, (3) the deposition process is controlled at room temperature, which is suitable for all flexible substrates, (4) the sputtered ZnO thin film has relatively high piezoelectric coefficients compared to a piezoelectric aluminum nitride (AlN) thin film (Giordano et al., 2009), and (5) a ZnO thin film, which is a nonferroelectric material, does not require electrical poling under a high electrical field (Chang et al., 2010) compared with general ferroelectric materials (such as PZT bulk/film, polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), and polyurea).

In addition, we determined a suitable thickness of the polyethylene terephthalate (PET) flexible substrate and superior compactness of crystal grains of the ZnO thin film as the piezoelectric layer using an radio frequency (RF) magnetron sputtering deposition method at less than 70°C. In comparison with conventional silicon and other thick metal beam substrates, low Young’s modulus of the thin PET plate can provide superior deflection. The designed ultraviolet (UV)-curable resin lump structure as proof mass can be rapidly manufactured into any geometrical pattern on PET substrates to the control operation frequency using a lithography-free method.

This study developed a new self-powered flexible piezoelectric power harvester with a storage module. To investigate the piezoelectric composite cantilever plate, ANSYS® version 11.0 (ANSYS, Inc. (NASDAQ: ANSS)) finite element analysis (FEA) was used to analyze the complex three-dimensional (3D)-coupled field vibration structures. Static analysis, modal analysis, and harmonic response analysis were performed to determine a suitable thickness of the PET substrate, structural modal parameters, frequency response functions, and output voltage. In the fabrication process, the piezoelectric ZnO thin film was deposited between the aluminum (Al) and copper (Cu) electrodes. The Al thin film as the bottom electrode was deposited on the PET substrate using physical vapor deposition because of its superior adhesion with the PET substrate and lattice constant matching with ZnO. The ZnO thin film with superior compactness and more even distribution of crystal grains with a high (002) diffraction peak at 2θ = 34.44° and full width at half maximum (FWHM) at 0.422° was deposited using RF magnetron sputtering. To fabricate the selectively deposited UV-curable resin lump structures as proof mass, electrospinning and stereolithography techniques were used to construct various patterns on the rear side of the PET-based piezoelectric composite plate, which can adjust the resonant frequencies of the composite cantilever plate to achieve larger deflection. Therefore, piezoelectric ZnO thin-film harvesters can harvest energy in small working spaces. In addition, they have a low operating frequency with low-level excitation and high deflection response compared with traditional PZT-based bulk ceramic vibrational structures, demonstrate long-term stability, and can be used at a low cost in clean energy applications.

sec.title: Design concepts and the fabrication process
Generalized vibration microharvester model
sec.p: A self-powered vibration-induced piezoelectric power harvester was designed to convert mechanical vibration into electrical power. Figure 1(a) shows a schematic model of vibration energy conversion. The mechanical behavior of a vibrating piezoelectric harvester can be modeled using a seismic mass (m) bonded on a spring (k) corresponding to the stiffness or a damping (bm) corresponding to the mechanical losses of the structure. A displacement (y(t)) is utilized to vibrate the rigid house, which results in differential movement (x(t)) between the mass and the house; thus, the relative displacement of mass was (Uz(t)). Fig. 1 (b) shows the composite cantilever plate as a harvester with a rectifying circuit (B) and a capacitor (C) as the battery. An ambient vibration amplitude at the anchor side induced the vertical deflection in the front end of the cantilever plate. The piezoelectric layer on the composite structure deformed when the cantilever plate oscillated with mass. The mechanical strain in the layer induces AC voltage through the piezoelectric effect. The d31 piezoelectric mode of the ZnO piezoelectric thin film was fabricated. The resulting charge was perpendicular to the piezoelectric layer surface.

sec.title: Predication of output voltage
sec.p: To investigate the complex power harvester of the flexible piezoelectric composite cantilever plate, the FEA package ANSYS version 11.0 was used to predict the coupled field behavior. The schematic layout of the flexible composite plate and designed parameters are shown in Figure 2(a). Three cases were used to verify the energy conversion behavior. The dimensions of these cases are shown in Table 1. A thick and stiff substrate exhibits a smaller vertical tip deflection and insufficient output voltage. However, the stiffness of the thin substrate was weak, which caused a warping effect because of thermal deformation (Pan et al., 2010) during the ZnO deposition process. Therefore, a PET substrate with thickness of 125 µm was achieved. The thickness of the piezoelectric ZnO thin film was 2 µm. A 30-µm-thick Cu foil was used as the top electrode. The bottom electrode of the Al layer was neglected in the finite element model. In comparison with the other layers, the Al layer (0.2-µm-thick and Young’s modulus of 40 × 109 N/m2) deposited on the PET substrate was thinner than the ZnO and Cu layers and may not be crucial to the simulation results of deflection and induced voltage. Moreover, Young’s modulus of the Al layer was insufficient to influence the internal tensile and compressive strain distribution in the composite plate compared with ZnO and Cu layers. The schematic illustration of this power harvester module is shown in Figure 2(b), which consists of a single flexible harvester and a rectifying storage module.

sec.title: Microharvester fabrication process
sec.p: The interface adhesion strength between the ZnO and indium tin oxide (ITO) films was easily reduced under a periodic mechanical stress (Chang et al., 2011; Li et al., 2012). To solve this problem, the 0.2-µm-thick Al thin film was deposited on the 125-µm-thick PET substrate using physical vapor deposition. The Al thin film was selected as the bottom electrode because of its low sheet resistance (the 0.2-µm-thick Al film was 9.7 Ohm/Sq; the 0.2-µm-thick ITO was 117.5 Ohm/Sq, which were measured using a four-point probe (5601Y SHEET RESISTIVITY METER; Quatek Co.)), excellent adhesion, and lattice constant matching with ZnO. The 2-µm-thick ZnO thin film with (002) c-axis as the preferred orientation was deposited on the Al/PET flexible plate, as shown in Figure 6(a). The ZnO thin film was developed at room temperature with RF power of 75 W, a mixed gas (O2/Ar + O2) of 60%, chamber pressure of 15 mTorr, base pressure of 6 × 10−6 Torr, and a Zn (99.995%) target. The X-ray diffractor (XRD) results in Figure 6(b) show a high ZnO (002) diffraction peak at 2θ = 34.44° and FWHM of 0.422° with excellent piezoelectricity property. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) observations of cross section and surface morphology are shown in Figure 6(c) to (e). The crystallite size of Al films deposited on the PET substrate was uniform. The ZnO thin film was deposited on the Al/PET conductive plate, the crystallite structure comprises several circle-like structured grains, and uniform grain size distribution was homogeneous with the smooth surface. In addition, the optimal sputtering parameters of the ZnO thin film for optimal photoluminescence (PL) characteristics were proposed (Hsieh et al., 2007) by Chen et al. The result showed that only UV light (379 nm wavelength) was found. The band gap of ZnO was 3.27 eV, which matches the photon energy of the characteristic UV light, indicating that the ZnO thin films were effectively deposited (Lin et al., 2001). Finally, a 30-µm-thick layer of Cu foil was stacked as a top electrode; the flexible power harvester is shown in Figure 6(f). Figure 7(a) shows the SEM observation of the ZnO/Al/PET surface morphology, which was smooth before and after the vibration test. However, the SEM observation shows interfacial crack propagation and considerable delamination phenomena on the surface of ZnO/ITO/PET after the vibration test, as shown in Figure 7(b). It indicates that the adhesion strength of the Al film between ZnO film and PET substrate is superior to that of the ITO film.

sec.title: Fabrication of UV-curable resin lump structures
sec.p: To fabricate the selectively deposited UV-curable resin lump structures as proof mass, electrospinning (Pu et al., 2011) and stereolithography (Maruo and Ikuta, 2002) techniques were used to directly draw patterns on the rear side of the PET-based piezoelectric composite substrate, as shown in Figure 8(a). This lithography-free method can improve the imprinting process (Pan et al., 2010), which can be applied to transfer UV-curable resin configurations onto a PET substrate. Electrospinning equipment in tandem with UV light source (LCS LIGHTNINGCURE™; Hamamatsu Co.), high-voltage power supply (HP 6515A), X–Y stage (TL-ST9090-50; Tanlian Electro Optics Co.), and infusion pump (KDS 101; KD Scientific) were assembled, as shown in Figure 8(b). The UV-curable resin was selectively spun on the PET flexible substrate using a high-voltage electric field (10 × 105 V/m) and controllable infusion pump (1 mL/min). Subsequently, the UV light exposes the patterns immediately to solidify the resin (exposure dosage at 400 mJ/cm2) based on layer-by-layer processing.

sec.title: Experimental setup and power generating testing
sec.p: The harvester was placed on a vibration platform of a shaker (BK4800; B&K) with an adjustable vibration frequency. To supply suitable acceleration to the harvester, the amplitude of vibration was set at a fixed displacement (u0 = 33 µm). The shaker can be programmably controlled by the function generator. The induced voltage signal from the harvester was measured using the oscilloscope (54622D; Agilent). A laser displacement meter (LK-G5001V; KEYENCE) can be used to measure the vertical deflection at the free end of the cantilever plate. The measurement system is schematically shown in Figure 9. Figure 10 shows that the power harvesting system of Case 3 consisted of the rectifying bridge and a storage electrolytic capacitor.

sec.title: Testing the prototype of power harvesting system
sec.p:
Case 1 was directly excited at fixed amplitude of the vibration source and scanned from 340 to 370 Hz. Cases 2 and 3 were scanned from 290 to 340 Hz and from 200 to 250 Hz, respectively. The cantilever tip deflection was measured using a laser displacement meter. The vibration amplitude at the anchor side was measured, as shown in Figure 11(a). The graph in Figure 11(b) to (d) recorded using an oscillograph shows the resonant frequency and OCV signal. The 227 Hz mode of Case 3 is the uniform bending mode, which exhibited the largest tip deflection and maximal OCV of 2.4 V. Table 4 tabulates the peak voltages, OCV and close-circuit voltage (CCV), tip deflection, DC across the capacitor, and peak power for the experiment. The simulation and experimental results were consistent, especially the resonant frequencies and induced peak voltages. In addition, the rectifying bridge circuit consists of four ST(SGS) 1N5711 Schottky diodes (STMicroelectronics) that had a lower forward voltage drop (approximately 0.2 V); however, the rectifying bridge circuit consumes electric field potential of approximately 0.4 V. A 39 nF Mylar capacitor was selected as the wave filter because it charges faster than storage electrolytic capacitors. The graph in Figure 12, which was recorded using an oscillograph, shows the operation frequency and the DC voltage across a Mylar capacitor after rectification. The DC voltage of Case 3 was 2 V, the DC voltage of Case 2 was 1.2 V, and the DC voltage of Case 1 was 0.14 V. The simulated and experimental results show that the maximal vertical tip deflection and vibration-induced voltage are inversely proportional to the damping ratio of the structure. sec.p: To measure the output power, the load resistance was connected in parallel to convert the mechanical vibration into the AC load voltage. Subsequently, the three cases were connected to an external resistance load between the two electrodes. The CCV was measured at the first mode resonance as a function of load resistance. According to the I–V test, the internal resistive load with various ZnO thicknesses was within 2–5 MO (Chang et al., 2010). The external resistive load must be regulated to match the output voltage; the matching of the external resistive load and the optimal power density was achieved by fabricating ZnO-based harvesters with a ZnO thin film with a constant thickness of 2 µm. The measurement results show that the load voltage increases in conjunction with the load resistance; Case 1 was up to 0.24 V, Case 2 was up to 1.12 V, and Case 3 was up to 2.18 V (Figure 13). In addition, Figure 14 shows output power of 0.56 µW from input vibrations of 67.06 m/s2 at 227 Hz for Case 3. Case 2 produced 0.14 µW from input vibrations of 130 m/s2 at 316 Hz. Case 1 produced 0.005 µW from input vibrations of 146 m/s2 at 355 Hz.

sec.title: Electricity charging and power harvesting system applications
sec.p: The experimental result of this power harvesting system shows that the charge performance of the storage capacitor is proportional to the peak power. Therefore, the charge efficiency of Case 3 was superior to that of the other cases. The power harvesting system of Case 3 was tested under 227 Hz (Case 3 was designed to resonate at 227 Hz). The charging results of Case 3 are shown in Figure 15. The DC voltages across the storage electrolytic capacitors (100 and 10 µF) after rectification were measured. The 100 µF storage capacitor required 2250 s to accumulate sufficient electrical energy of approximately 1.572 V to drive an external flash light-emitting diode (LED) module, as shown in Figure 16(a), and the 10 µF storage capacitor required 330 s to store electrical energy (nearly 1.58 V).

caption.p: Charging results of Case 3 using 100 and 10 µF storage capacitors at 227 Hz.
DC: direct current.

Vibration energy scavenging for self-powered flash signal LED module: (a) excited at 227 Hz by shaker and (b) excited at 56 Hz with tip deflection of 2125 µm using a domestic electric fan (wind speed: 150 m/min and airflow: 34 m3/min).
LED: light-emitting diode.

sec.p: In addition, the harvesting system was also driven using a domestic electric fan to scavenge wind power under an nonresonant condition. Figure 16(b) shows the experimental process of airflow affecting the power harvester. In an airflow (wind speed of 150 m/min and airflow of 34 m3/min), the power harvester regularly sheds alternating vortices on either side because of the turbulence effect. The resulting pressure differential caused by the vortices forces the power harvester to move in an oscillating motion (vibration frequency of 56 Hz and tip deflection of 2125 µm were measured using a laser displacement meter). Following AC to DC rectification, the maximal DC output voltage across a 39 nF capacitor remained at 3.7 V. The maximal power of 1.25 µW was obtained with a resistive load of 2 MΩ. When the harvesting system was running, the storage module (using a 10 µF capacitor) quickly accumulated sufficient electric potential in approximately 47 s and overcame the forward voltage of the LED module. Subsequently, the LED module was directly lit up four times for 2 s by the limited electrical energy outputted from a storage capacitor.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article presents a flexible piezoelectric power harvester of a PET-based cantilever structure that combines a low forward voltage drop rectifying circuit and a storage capacitor to store the induced voltage. The Al thin film was selected as the bottom electrode because of its excellent adhesion on the PET substrate and the lattice constant matching with the ZnO film. A high-quality ZnO thin film with a preferred orientation of the (002) c-axis was sputtered on the Al/PET conductive plate. A comparison of the ZnO/Al/PET with the ZnO/ITO/PET cases after the vibration test showed that the adhesion strength of the Al film between the ZnO film and PET substrate was superior to that of the ITO film. To adjust the resonant frequency and obtain a larger deflection of the composite cantilever plates, direct-write electrospinning techniques with stereolithography techniques were used to selectively deposit the UV-curable resin lump structures. ANSYS FEA simulations were used to predict the structural modal parameters, frequency response functions, and the induced voltage of the power harvesters. The results showed that the harvester of Case 3 achieved a maximal OCV of up to 2.4 V, CCV of up to 2.18 V, which is 0.56 µW/cm2, and DC voltage of 2 V across the capacitor after rectification. Moreover, this study developed the self-powered storage system to drive a flash signal LED module under both resonant and nonresonant conditions.
